info.game_comments:
2001 Tournament of Champions quarterfinal game 4.

(Jimmy: ¡Hola!  Soy Jimmy de la Clue Crew.  Hoy en Jeopardy! hablamos español--¡y más!)

(1, 1).clue: African-American writer Chester Himes exploded with "A Rage in" this section of Manhattan

(2, 1).clue: The length of these ladylike accessories is denoted by buttons;  16-button ones are formal length

(3, 1).clue: This man who found Livingstone also helped spread Congolese sleeping sickness while establishing trading stations

(4, 1).clue: Golfer Greg Norman was born in this country

(5, 1).clue: A former school librarian, she helped organize the Texas Book Festival to raise money for local libraries

(6, 1).clue: If you want to show off your bronco riding & calf roping skills enter this public exhibition, hombre

(1, 2).clue: John Steinbeck describes this title fish processing area in Monterey, Ca. as "A poem, a stink, a grating noise"

(2, 2).clue: Prince William's alma mater, this school known for its "playing fields" had a jacket named for it

(3, 2).clue: The first recorded epidemic of this salivary gland-swelling disease was described around 410 B.C. in Greece

(4, 2).clue: Germany's Jan Ullrich gained glory through this pursuit

(5, 2).clue: This first lady was all smiles in the photo seen here, taken at her surprise birthday party in 1954

(6, 2).clue: My wife claims I am muy this, manly & assertive, just like the Village People song

(1, 3).clue: In an Erich Maria Remarque novel, "The army report confined itself to a single sentence"--this, the book's title
(1, 3).correct response: All Quiet on the Western Front

(2, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from a "boat.")  Wear this neckline whose name is French for "boat" & you'll be cruising in a style popular in the '20s & '30s

(3, 3).clue: Causing thousands of deaths, abnormally high temperatures in 1803 led to Spanish outbreaks of this colorful fever

(4, 3).clue: Sport that made Jean-Claude Killy famous

(5, 3).clue: Born Elizabeth Bloomer, she sprang up in Chicago in 1918

(6, 3).clue: These irregular soldiers who harass the enemy have a type of warfare named for them

(1, 4).clue: Machines are forbidden in this remote land, the subject of an 1872 satire by Samuel Butler

(2, 4).clue: People magazine said this rock star's daughter Jade launched her line of jewelry in a see-through dress

(3, 4).clue: Deadly outbreaks of cholera & typhus struck British, French & Russian soldiers equally in this 1853-56 war

(4, 4).clue: Auto racer born in Dunbartonshire, Scotland in 1939

(5, 4).clue: Her feelings about thespians might have been improved when Sarah Bernhardt reportedly saved her life in 1880

(6, 4).clue: Lorne Greene & his amigos could find this source of great & sudden wealth near the Ponderosa

(1, 5).clue: The high-spirited mistresses Ford & Page are the title married women of this place in a Shakespeare play

(2, 5).clue: In the 1800s it was fashionable to wear a cap named for this woman who stabbed Jean-Paul Marat

(3, 5).clue: A devastating 17th c. plague epidemic on this island 58 miles south of Sicily killed 1 in 7 people

(4, 5).clue: This British-born boxer won the WBC heavyweight title in 1992

(5, 5).clue: Largely an invalid, Eliza, wife of this "Tennessee Tailor", made only 2 public appearances as first lady

(6, 5).clue: This type of person is a fan of a hobby or activity, con mucho gusto

(1, 1).clue: Round, wrinkled, green seed or yellow seed are differences in the 7 traits of these plants Mendel studied

(2, 1).clue: Lots of places have an Oktoberfest, but the town of Liberal in this state has an Oztoberfest

(4, 1).clue: This "Man from Hope" was a '68 recipient

(5, 1).clue: An Actors Studio founder once said of this play, "Who wants to see a play about an unhappy traveling salesman?"

(6, 1).clue: A baby may do this when this plaything bounces away

(1, 2).clue: A father contributes an X chromosome to create a daughter & this chromosome to create a son

(2, 2).clue: Snowy peaks surround Bishkek, the capital of this country (hint:  most of the people speak Kyrgyz)

(3, 2).clue: Soviets Send First Man Into Space!

(4, 2).clue: A scholar was born with the 1958 selection of this man who wrote the song "Me And Bobby McGee"

(5, 2).clue: Just before its fateful 1912 voyage began, a deckhand asserted, "God himself couldn't sink this ship"

(6, 2).clue: The crust end of a loaf of bread, or to make well

(1, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew cracks the case.)  It's the total number of cells in this yellow egg yolk

(2, 3).clue: Seen here in all its glory, Waimea Canyon on this island is known as the "Grand Canyon of the Pacific"

(3, 3).clue: Joe Namath & the Jets Win the Super Bowl!

(4, 3).clue: He was on the Rhodes to success in '65 but got Gore-d in the 2000 presidential primaries

(5, 3).clue: About this film Irving Thalberg predicted, "Forget it, Louis.  No Civil War picture ever made a nickel"

(6, 3).clue: Possess, or divide into 2 equal pieces

(1, 4).clue: Oxygen is a waste product of this metabolic process in green plants

(2, 4).clue: When visiting this London palace that was home to Princess Di, stop for a spot of tea at the Orangery

(3, 4).clue: Bolsheviks Kill the Czar & His Family!

(4, 4).clue: He wasn't focused properly when he studied law at Oxford;  astronomy was his calling & a space telescope was named for him

(5, 4).clue: In 1839 French painter Paul Delaroche said, "From today painting is dead" after an exhibition of these

(6, 4).clue: Makes noise like a donkey, or to cook fat-browned meat slowly in a small amount of liquid in a covered pot

(1, 5).clue: Chitin is the main component in this supportive outside covering of lobsters & insects

(2, 5).clue: The 2 "K" towns--one in Florida & one in Idaho--that were home to Hemingway

(4, 5).clue: Some say Rob Lowe's "West Wing" character is based on this 1984 Rhodes Scholar, now an ABC News commentator

(5, 5).clue: Returning from Munich in 1938 he predicted, "I believe it is peace in our time"

(6, 5).clue: Maybe, just perhaps, this small arachnid will attack your plant

(0, 0).clue: It's from the Greek for "a place for watching"
